summary:
Canan Marasligil (Ja’anan Marashligil) (she/they) is a feminist writer, artist, literary translator, editor and curator of literary and cultural programmes, whose practice spans from performing, giving workshops to making podcasts. She is active in the fields of literature, comics, photography, cultural criticism. Throughout their work, Canan advocates for representation, equality and diversity. Canan works in English, French, Dutch and Turkish, and has a fair command of Spanish.

A multidisciplinary approach is central to how Canan works, with their practices feeding one another to create spaces where we can collectively engage with art, culture, literature and ignite change through creativity. 

In Spring 2023, Canan will launch The Attention Span newsletter which focuses on reflection, analysis and imagination, offering a closer look into their work and practice. Each issue (every two weeks) contains a short essay on a topic related to Canan’s work, a nerdy look at translation, a page from one of their notebooks, and a list of interesting things she is reading, watching or listening to. 
For more information visit https://theattentionspan.com/subscribe

Throughout my work, I try to find connection points between: 
- individual contribution – which requires time alone to work, research, think and reflect, to create before we can share anything with the world, 
- and collective action, which requires spaces where the individuals can safely express themselves, share their work that will then connect within this collective. 

Throughout the years, I have worked within the cultural and literary scenes in countries such as Belgium, the Netherlands, UK, France, and Turkey, including partnerships in Algeria, Morocco, Germany and more, as well as on different levels from the collective and independent scenes to institutional and governmental organisations.', 'title': 'Freelance writer, literary translator, artist, performer, editor, podcaster, curator,...', 'employment_type': 'Freelance'}]}, {'company': {'id': None, 'name': 'The Attention Span Newsletter', 'logo': None, 'url': None, 'employees': {'start': None, 'end': None}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2023}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Online', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2023}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'company': 'The Attention Span Newsletter', 'description': 'Canan (Ja’anan) Marasligil has launched The Attention Span Newsletter, in e-mail and podcast format. 

Each issue contains a short essay, a nerdy look at translation, a notebook page, and a list of interesting things to read, watch or listen to. 

Whether you are a writer, a translator, a reader, a professional working in the arts, culture or literature, or someone who likes to take the time to reflect on the world we live in through the lens of culture, art, translation, poetry and literature, The Attention Span Newsletter is for you. 

Subscribe to join the newsletter, or simply find ‘The Attention Span’ on your favourite pod catcher, including Spotify, Apple Podcasts, Overcast… www.theattentionspan.com/subscribe', 'title': 'Creator and Producer', 'employment_type': 'Freelance'}]}, {'company': {'id': 10009532, 'name': 'Read My World', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/D4E0BAQHIZsI4oLWisg/company-logo_400_400/0/1688136420111?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=sRXGw3e17le255kQQUnKzTfKrEL_OeGAdGAyCrcQnZw', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/read-my-world/', 'employees': {'start': 11, 'end': 50}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Amsterdam Area, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'company': 'Read My World', 'description': 'Currently working on the Read My World 2023 edition.

I am part of the programming team of the International Literature Festival of Amsterdam Read My World. 
After a focus on Turkey in 2018, Morocco in 2019, and Europe in 2020, the festival shifted to thematic focuses with the editions entitled With Care in 2021, and Joy & Sorrow in 2022. 

I have always loved this festival and its approach towards programming literature from different places: every year, they invite two curators from the country they are focusing on and the programme team works in collaboration with these people. I find this approach key in creating spaces of encounter where all parties - hosts, guests, audiences - all can share, feel, debate, read, perform, learn,... on an equal level. After all, isn’t it where literature’s power lies? Creating those spaces through our imaginations...', 'title': 'Programme Curator', 'employment_type': 'Freelance'}]}, {'company': {'id': None, 'name': None, 'logo': None, 'url': None, 'employees': {'start': None, 'end': None}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': None, 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'company': None, 'description': 'Translation is at the centre of everything I do, including how I approach cities. I take languages and the city’s public space as a starting point to explore how the process of translation takes place and how people interact with the languages in their city. This vibrant and interactive multilingualism throughout urban landscapes is a central feature to how we imagine the future of our cities and part of how we want to build communities.

Since I started it in 2015 at Copenhagen university, City in Translation has travelled across Europe and beyond, and materialised into residencies, exhibitions, workshops and a chapter in a Routledge publication.
